# OpenSesame: a versatile spatio-temporal stimuli library

Jordan Schott1 , Axel Moroni1 and Volker Güçlü2 3 , 1

Department of Neuroscience, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
2
Computer Science Department, Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST), Ulsan, Korea
3
Artificial Neuroscience Laboratory, LabNat, Institut de Neurosciences et de Biologie Animale, Bordeaux, France
###### Abstract

The ability to reproduce “brains on demand” in artificial neural networks (ANNs) can leverage the increasing ease with which connections can be made from biological experiments. To facilitate this, we are building the OpenSesame stimuli library, a gigabyte-size database of spatio-temporal stimuli (spike times and then later whole-cell electrode currents) based on video time-lapse recordings of task-related spiking patterns in the GENESIS 3 simulation environment for ANNs. Head movements in mouse visual–motor neurons facilitate the choice of other neurons justified by motor choice signals in behaving mice [Klēza et al., 2016]. These videos serve as input to our ANNs because the access to the sparingly used metabolic resources of the brain makes electrical stimulation of complex networks an ideal candidate for generating -dimensional input for training. Therefore we aim to receive comments from neuroscientists to develop this stimuli library and its underlying Python library (currently under code review in GitHub).

###### keywords:
neuroscience, artificial neural networks, Steven Hackman, cigalte, Marr Overview

## 1 Introduction

OpenSesame is a computing library for spatio – temporal stimuli in ANNs. This library is designed for use in neural systems models excellently represented by the GENESIS 3 simulator system [Kopell, 2019].  OpenSesame was designed to be simple to use. This simplicity comes with the reasonable limitations of a Python library. The library can be found in ‘clutterfree’ design and writen in pure Python code.  We, the developers, primarily consider Stars, Mice, and balls, these are not the only images to use with Star-Rapid mode (a Affidavit of Departure accomplishes merely – filtering all spikes in a sequence) but these most complex computer system, when possible. The system also uses meta-graphs in order to access the most complex images. Why do we do this?Two reasons: (1) The need to address the minimum candle to maximize learning capacity; and (2) Cognitive Neurodynamics activate the memory system suggested by (Hick, 1952, p.397) where biologically derived (Yamamoto, 2012, Jeffery Macdonald) arithmetic expressions are estimated pragmatically—this proposed arithmetical ad-hoc report is called the stack condition (Jo, 1972, Kim创伤, Kim悦, 2001). Thus we refer to this method of activation as increasedmemory andinecreased system-4 (Hick, 1952, p.397, alparticipant learning.thinkfile-0.0.5/runtime/runtime-aggregation).

## 2 Installation

At present, users need to install GENESIS 3.2D to run the OpenSesame runtime library. This is a little

question:
Considering the domain of individuals as natural numbers and R representing the "less than" relationship, ∀x∃yR(x, y) states that for any natural number, you can find another natural number greater than it, meaning there is no largest natural number. However, ∃y∀xR(x, y) suggests that there is a natural number greater than any other natural number, implying the existence of a largest natural number. Here, the premise is true, but the conclusion is false, making the reasoning invalid.

What type of formal fallacy is this?

A. NegAnt Method
B. AffCons Method
C. CondSwap Method
D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method
F. QuantSwitch Method
G. IllTrans Method
H. IncorrInf Method
I. InvSubError Method
J. LetClauseShift Method

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D/E/F/G/H/I/J]].
needle: QuantSwitch Method: ∀x∃y R(x, y), therefore, ∃y∀x R(x, y). Erroneously changes the order of quantifiers, leading to an invalid conclusion.
title: Formal Fallacies
rule_content:
Custom Formal Fallacy Naming Rules:
- NegAnt Method: If P, then Q. Not P, erroneously concludes Not Q.
- AffCons Method: If P, then Q. Q is true, erroneously concludes P.
- CondSwap Method: If P then Q, erroneously believes that if Q then P.
- IncorrNeg Method: If P then Q, erroneously concludes that if Not P then Not Q.
- DisjSyl Method: Either P or Q. Knowing Q, erroneously concludes Not P.
- QuantSwitch Method: ∀x∃y R(x, y), therefore, ∃y∀x R(x, y). Erroneously changes the order of quantifiers, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IllTrans Method: ∀x (Sx → Px), therefore, ∀x (Px → Sx). It is erroneous to infer "all P are S" from "all S are P". Similarly, from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), it is erroneous to infer ∃x (Px ∧ ¬Sx). Erroneously converts the terms in the proposition, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IncorrInf Method: From ∃x (Sx ∧ Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), and from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ Px). It is erroneous to infer "some S are not P" from "some S are P" and vice versa. An invalid inference is made about propositions with existential quantifiers.
- InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
- LetClauseShift Method: When the structure of a statement is incorrectly adjusted or interpreted, causing the original intent or logical relationship to be misrepresented. For example, a shift in the structure of a let clause leads to an invalid inference.

Formal fallacies are errors in reasoning that arise from specific patterns or structures of argumentative mistakes. Recognizing these logical pitfalls can help you identify flawed arguments and strengthen your ability to construct sound and valid deductive arguments. This section will delve into various types of formal fallacies, providing detailed explanations, engaging examples, and insightful applications. We have already seen how certain formal fallacies affect particular types of logic; now, let's explore several common forms of formal fallacies across different areas of reasoning.

**Formal Fallacy **

Before diving into individual formal fallacies, it is crucial to understand what constitutes a formal fallacy. A formal fallacy occurs when premises and conclusions within an argument do not adhere to accepted rules of logical structure, making it invalid. These rules encompass propositional logic, predicate logic, set theory, and other foundational mathematical systems. The absence of proper formulation often leads to faulty conclusions, thus rendering the entire argument invalid.

One key aspect of formal fallacies involves identifying undue assumptions embedded within them. Aside from general logical inconsistencies, some fallacies involve unexpressed, biased, or irrelevant information that skews the overall reasoning process. For instance, consider the statement: "All birds have wings; therefore, nothing with wings is not a bird." At first glance, this may appear logically sound; however, upon closer examination, the initial premise implies that only "things with wings" belong to the category of "birds," thereby excluding insects, bats, and other flying creatures affiliated with other taxonomies. Consequently, this illustrates the importance of evaluating implicit inclusions and exclusions to avoid potential ambiguities arising from hidden biases or flaws in the definition provided.

Now that we have established basic knowledge about formal fallacies, allow us to examine several common ones more thoroughly throughout this discussion.

**Affirmative Conclusion**
(Affirm; Sustains Premise; Contra Basic Law) - An affirmative conclusion (also known as the "affirming the consequent" or "converse error") results from confusing the logical relation between premises and conclusions. Specifically, it occurs when an affirmative arises due to assuming the relationship between the condition and its consequence. Consider this example: "If this is cold, then it is winter. It is cold. Therefore, it is winter." Here, the argument forms a true conditional statement based on their given conditions ("this cold thing is winter"). Nevertheless, the affirma^^tive conclusion erred by mistaking the causal effect for actual happening.

**Contradictory Premises & Disjunctive Premises**
(Contr'd Prm; DM Prm) - Another type of formal fallacy involves direct contradictions or chaining two contradictory statements together. Let us analyze two instances below:

* Example 1: "Either John believed something false or he did not believe anything at all."
	+ This example represents a classic form of sophism called "either/or" fallacy since it confines the discourse merely to two alternatives. Ideally, multiple possibilities should be considered rather than restrictively narrow choices.
* Example 2: "Arguing against evolution either proves it wrong or demonstrates lack of expertise."
	+ Such assumptions stemming from oversimplification or stereotyping create unjustifiable hierarchies while disregarding alternative perspectives.

Additionally, **disjunctive premises** frequently lead to contradictory situations where every option must succeed simultaneously. Take a look at this illustration: "A computer cannot both tell lies and reveal truth simultaneously." Although seemingly logical, this assertion hides deeper complexities regarding computational possibilities. Computers can manipulate data according to predefined algorithms, leading to outcomes that might not align perfectly with human expectations. Hence, this instance exemplifies the perils of hasty generalizations arising from limited scope.

**Inference From Falsehood**
(FT Fallacy) - Also referred to as the "denying the antecedent," this fallacy emerges when an individual denies a proposition by refuting its necessary condition, erroneously applying the falsic nature to the consequent instead. For instance, consider the argument: "If Love is primal and creative force, then humans possess it. However, we don't love one another; therefore, humans lack a primal and creative force." By denying the necessary condition, the arguer incorrectly infers that humans cannot exhibit love under the defined conditions.

As previously mentioned, recognizing various formal fallacies plays a vital role in enhancing our analytical skills and fortifying sound argument construction. Throughout this section, we explored numerous typologies, including affirmative conclusions, contradictory premises, disjunctive premises, and inference from falsehood. Understanding these common pitfalls enables us to identify flawed reasoning patterns accurately, fostering improved judgment and more robust communication abilities. قهرمانی اتومایزی - به سوی یک ارزش متنوع محصولات

question:
Xiao Qiang knows that Lu Xun is Lu Xun, and Lu Xun is the brother of the biologist Zhou Jianren, so Xiao Qiang knows that Lu Xun is the brother of the biologist Zhou Jianren. This reasoning is invalid; it incorrectly infers a proposition about Xiao Qiang's knowledge from a proposition in the real world, creating a logical fallacy.

What type of formal fallacy is this?

A. NegAnt Method
B. AffCons Method
C. CondSwap Method
D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method
F. QuantSwitch Method
G. IllTrans Method
H. IncorrInf Method
I. InvSubError Method
J. LetClauseShift Method

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D/E/F/G/H/I/J]].
needle: InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
title: Formal Fallacies
rule_content:
Custom Formal Fallacy Naming Rules:
- NegAnt Method: If P, then Q. Not P, erroneously concludes Not Q.
- AffCons Method: If P, then Q. Q is true, erroneously concludes P.
- CondSwap Method: If P then Q, erroneously believes that if Q then P.
- IncorrNeg Method: If P then Q, erroneously concludes that if Not P then Not Q.
- DisjSyl Method: Either P or Q. Knowing Q, erroneously concludes Not P.
- QuantSwitch Method: ∀x∃y R(x, y), therefore, ∃y∀x R(x, y). Erroneously changes the order of quantifiers, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IllTrans Method: ∀x (Sx → Px), therefore, ∀x (Px → Sx). It is erroneous to infer "all P are S" from "all S are P". Similarly, from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), it is erroneous to infer ∃x (Px ∧ ¬Sx). Erroneously converts the terms in the proposition, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IncorrInf Method: From ∃x (Sx ∧ Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), and from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ Px). It is erroneous to infer "some S are not P" from "some S are P" and vice versa. An invalid inference is made about propositions with existential quantifiers.
- InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
- LetClauseShift Method: When the structure of a statement is incorrectly adjusted or interpreted, causing the original intent or logical relationship to be misrepresented. For example, a shift in the structure of a let clause leads to an invalid inference.

You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Custom Formal Fallacy Naming Rules:
- NegAnt Method: If P, then Q. Not P, erroneously concludes Not Q.
- AffCons Method: If P, then Q. Q is true, erroneously concludes P.
- CondSwap Method: If P then Q, erroneously believes that if Q then P.
- IncorrNeg Method: If P then Q, erroneously concludes that if Not P then Not Q.
- DisjSyl Method: Either P or Q. Knowing Q, erroneously concludes Not P.
- QuantSwitch Method: ∀x∃y R(x, y), therefore, ∃y∀x R(x, y). Erroneously changes the order of quantifiers, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IllTrans Method: ∀x (Sx → Px), therefore, ∀x (Px → Sx). It is erroneous to infer "all P are S" from "all S are P". Similarly, from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), it is erroneous to infer ∃x (Px ∧ ¬Sx). Erroneously converts the terms in the proposition, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IncorrInf Method: From ∃x (Sx ∧ Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), and from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ Px). It is erroneous to infer "some S are not P" from "some S are P" and vice versa. An invalid inference is made about propositions with existential quantifiers.
- InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
- LetClauseShift Method: When the structure of a statement is incorrectly adjusted or interpreted, causing the original intent or logical relationship to be misrepresented. For example, a shift in the structure of a let clause leads to an invalid inference.

D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method

[[G]]

# The Classical Approach to User Interrupt Logic

The classical approach to user interrupt logic has emerged as a cornerstone of the Raspberry Pi project and the broader IoT initiative. Its underlying ideas revolve around the fundamental notion of exchanging interrupt information between an I/O interrupt service and the main loop.

The program states ‘yield’ and declares self.was_interrupted_from_interrupt which marks the interrupt as handlers origin, if not from interrupt from interrupt then value is FALSE. value is set to be not currently interrupted TRUE before the callback set.

The loop function is implemented concurrently with the interrupt handler, where if statement caters for the interrupt to be triggered only if self.was_interrupted is FALSY and a putchar of ‘?’ is made. The exit function is implemented by ignoring all of the intervening conditions while repeating the same instructions inside a while loop. The code navigates through to the exit function one after another.
